intro: Spergularia clevelandi, commonly known as Cleveland's sandspurry, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of southern California. It is a low-growing, mat-forming species that thrives in sandy and rocky soils, often found in dunes and coastal scrub habitats. The plant produces small, white or pale pink flowers that bloom from spring to early summer. Its leaves are typically fleshy and succulent, adapted to conserve water in arid environments. Spergularia clevelandi is considered a rare and endemic species, highlighting its ecological significance to local biodiversity.
